What do I need to care for my boots?
>Old cotton t shirt (one for cleaning, another for applying conditioners)
>Horsehair brush ($10-15)
>Wooden shoe trees ($10-15)
>Light conditioner like Lexol/Bck4
>Heavy conditioner (if you live in terrible snow/rain areas) Sno seal/Obernauf LP
>Don't forget that boots need time to dry properly, rotate them and don't wear them daily for too long

How do I deal with x stain?
>mud: allow it to dry then brush off
>salt: water and cloth as soon as possible
>saturated wet: allow the boot to dry for a full day, stuff with newspaper
>scuffs and scratches: buff vigorously with horsehair brush

Some conditioners, even if tgey don't have mink oil, will darken the leather to a degree. Just recently I used the same conditioner on three pairs of shoes; one didn't change color at all, another darkened a little and the last one darkened a lot. I beleive it depends on the type of leather and how damaged or how long it's been since it's got proper treatment. The more damaged or cheaper, tge more it'll darken.

I would just cobdition the other boot to even out things if I were you, then see how they change as ypu wear them. They should regain ther original color, or very close to, with time and wearing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17424414
Shell is not a leather, it's a membrane from a horse's arse (more like lower back).

It is very difficult to produce, basically only one tannery in the world does it right (Horween in Chicago) and one more comes a distant second (Shinki Hikaku in Japan). All the rest are not worth considering.

Each horse only yields enough for like 2 pairs of footwear if you are lucky.

As if that wasn't bad enough already, it is also very difficult to work with. Very few shoemakers can use shell properly, because (among other issues) it has a tendency to snap when pulled, and making shoes requires pulling the leather over the last very hard.
For example Carmina says that for a specific boot model, they break on average 2 hides before successfully making the third. They stopped offering this model eventually.

So is it any good? I have a pair of boots in shell cordovan, and I am happy that I own one of my grail items, but honestly it's not very good.
It's a little rigid and inflexible. It does not crease, but it wrinkles in a unique way that makes it stand out. It's very shiny and changes color depending on the light, which also makes it stand out. In terms of scratches and scuffs, it feels almost impervious to such things. I have never worn them in the rain, they are completely waterproof because shell is non-porous (another unique quality) but they are known to get rain spots especially on lighter shell colors (mine are dark).

>>17424461
>so all the turdsday front delaminating could be from sizing up too much
not necessarily. they just use a really soft, flexible rubber at a lower thickness than danite so the edge works itself away from the midsole quickly. once its unstuck it really only takes a few missteps to chew up the section in front of the stiching. I suspect that's why you'll see a lot of recessed commando soles getting thicker towards the toe
the toplift coming off is basically down to thickness again plus I think they nail inside out instead of outside in so the toplift is likely only held on by glue

>>17425221
1: If you haven't already, get a vintage bottle of Salvador Dali Pour Homme. Easy to find on eBay, worst case scenario grab a sealed splash bottle and decant into an atomizer. The whole honey tobacco profile for Mugler Pure Havanne/Naxos/18.21 Man Made etc is close to a direct rip from this fragrance. You need the vintage though, which is still cheap. It's also very wearable today, especially since Sauvage Elixir and Beau Du Jour are mainstream.

If you have that go to these next:
Vintage Caron Pour un Homme. Skanky as shit, best kept secret if you like Kouros and Antaeus style frags.
Dior Jules
Dior Eau Sauvage. Vintage 1oz bottles are normally available on eBay.
Vermeil Pour Homme
Maxim's Pour Homme. Another underated classic animalic. Part of me is always greedy and doesn't want to recommend this but it's so good that I have to. Floral,leather, oakmoss, animalic.
Alain Delon Iquitos. The most beautiful fragrance for men I've ever smelled, and it's skanky as hell. Smells hot, tropical, sensual. There's cool history here with Dior rejecting the fragrance and then regretting it, and the frag was discontinued due to ingredient availability rather than reformulate. Get a mini on eBay at least, everyone should smell this one.

I can't stand florals in most men's frags today, the fact that frags like Lyric for Men, Toy Boy and Declaration Soir get pushed as good florals make me shake my head. Florals in the late 70s to early 90s were more common and still MANLY.

Paco Rabanne Tenerre . Similar spirit to Iquitos, different execution. Civet and honey, musk, moss, patchouli and leather with a bouquet on the side. Has a strange dusty vibe which is somehow pleasant.

Azarro Acteur. Leather bomb with a huge blood red rose note, voluptuous and sensual. Great use of nutmeg as well. Somewhat modern smelling too, could be released today as niche and people would go ape shit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17425368
2: Paloma Picasso Minotaure. Beautiful fragrance, works flawlessly today. Orange musky creamsickle. Works so well that Almariac decided to be a giant bitch and release the exact same fragrance again and call it Wake Up World but charge niche price. I'm not joking, it's the same fragrance, you can read about it on Fragrantica. save your money, buy a vintage bottle on eBay of the first formulation. Runs 50-70, juice smells fine as long as the box is sealed and unused.

Carlo Corinto for men. Soapy, herbal green leather Fougere with a strong and anachronistic raspberry note. I think Tom Ford got the idea for Tuscan Leather here.

Aramis Havana. Still my favorite tobacco fragrance. Orange,allspice, bay leaf, tobacco, rum and leather. This fragrance just feels passionate and alive. The rerelease isn't bad, but if you want the real deal look for the original blue bottles.

Cappucci Pour Homme. A rougher, more herbal and spicy Acqua Di Parma Colonia


Versace L'homme. Saving the best for last. Pure Italian, perfect mix of class and sleaze. Citrus, musk, leather. Not complicated but executed immaculately, back when Versace was run by the real talent. Easy to find the vintage on eBay, font style is different on the original bottles. Price is low but will skyrocket as supply dwindles.


That's it for now. I've tried to stick with ones that are readily available on eBay for less than $100, Iquitos is the exception but you can still get a mini which will last for years.

Now I am planning my first business trip, where I join the CEO of an startup to meet real estate agents, low level government employees and other consultants in major cities across the US. I never seen anyone in the company wear a suit, but I only ever saw them through ZOOM in their house.

I already have blue and white dress shirts and relatively nice v-neck Pullovers, different Styles of Polo Shirts as well as light/dark brown and dark blue Chino Pants. Can I get by with that or do I need to add (or take away) some items? I don’t want to look or come across like pic rel, but still “follow the rules“.

Also which shoes would work? I only have new balance sneakers and some Lacoste Boat shoes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
you might want a couple of suits if you want to look more formal, or just a couple jackets if yo want to look more casual, either one might be more appropriate depending on the specific work you do
what is it that you work as?
dress shirts are a must if you're meeting people on the clock in a number of jobs, though again, depends on your job
sneakers and boat shoes are most likely going to be too casual no matter the job, look for any type of brown dress shoe if you want to look formal or moccasin if you want to be on the casual side
>pic related
pic related is dressed for new years' eve 1999, to avoid looking like that you can, in order of importance:
not wear a black tie, especially with a black suit
not wear a white shirt, especially with a black suit
not wear a black suit
not wear a suit at all

>>17423273
Non watch people have the wrong idea about WR. You buy a watch with "overkill" WR not because you're going scuba diving the day you buy it, but because you don't want to worry about destroying it when you procrastinated on getting it serviced and it's 6 years overdue and you get caught in a downpour

That said, the screw down part is not what makes it water resistant per se, that just protects the stem from getting banged around which can bend it and cause the gasket to no longer seal. It's not unlike a crown guard or a recessed crown.

The customizability aspect is pretty desirable as well since lots of watches these days ship with straps that have questionable designs. Also if you order a strap from a manufacturer that uses Fournet straps, you’ll get raked across the coals and charged 3-4x what you’d pay if you bought direct.

>>17423741
It's one of the best looking G-Shocks. The timers are amazing but I hate not having the current time in all modes. The buttons are also a bitch to press, some oldfags even boiled the resin to make the buttons easier to press. The dual illuminator looks fantastic and it's a shame they don't put that feature on newer G-Shocks. Without a dual illuminator you have no idea what the charge level or alarms are in the dark on models like the GW-M5610U or the GW-6900. It's a medium sized watch for a G-Shock so I wouldn't recommend it for small wrists. Not the most comfortable but wearable. It's has been discontinued for a while but there is plenty of stock left.

tldr: kinda outdated but some better features not present on modern G-shocks and looks great
7/10

The nato does dress it down but you could even get the same watch without the flashy strap. Sometimes I feel it’s tacky and sometimes I feel like I miss it so I wear the bracelet seasonally.

eBay actually inspects their watches, Jomashop is known to be reliable, and Chrono24 I have never used but they hold the money you pay in escrow as a protection + it depends on the seller.

With all that said, this watch is too obscure to have much of a chance of many reps of it. Making a believable rep is a serious production so they generally only get their ROI if there will be many buyers think AP Royal oak or most stainless Rolex. You would be just fine, I had the same thoughts as you and paid retail at a shop for peace of mind since I was brand new and finally had enough money to buy my first “real watch”. My taste is very different now but I will keep this watch anyway because of the memories of it.

TLDR you should be fine. It also has a clear caseback for you to evaluate the finishing.

based welding thread

For my part, I am predicting that shirt+jacket+pantscore will take off bigtime as a trend this year. My projections see shirt+jacket+pantscore peaking in late winter/early spring with when it gets to be too warm to wear a coat yet too cold for short sleeves. This trend will die off in summer but we can expect to see a resurgence in the 4th quarter. The only reason i mention this cal group is because as i mentioned they are similar to my old friends and they share somewhat similar interests to me (namely vidya, music (bands i dont actively listen to but like), and even though i dont watch a lot, anime. Some of them work out too but im still a skinny dyel). To make friends with anyone else here seems like an insurmountable wall.
Yet i dont know how to talk to them without coming across as weird. I thought i could wait for a chance to say something during the semester if they were having a conversation about a topic i like but the chance never really came, and when it did i couldnt think of anything to say.
So ive probably already cemented myself as a shy autist in their minds, or at the very least weird.
I feel like i have more than enough to make friends here but i dont know how to take the first step.
When you made friends, did it just happen? Or did you have to work for it? Or a mix of both?
And where can i learn how to make friends?
I always hear "look for clubs on campus" but i genuinely think theres none here. The closest thing i can think of was my cal teacher holding after-class meetings in a nearby room for help with math homework. Which i didnt need because i already took a highschool class of cal 1 and 2 (it wasnt a college credit type thing but it helped me immensely this past semester and will help this next semester).
But it felt awkward getting my tests and quizzes back and seeing 95s-100s while everyone around me was lucky to get an 80. I saw the guy sitting in front of me trying to glance back at one of my test grades. Wonder what he thinks of me.
I feel terrible for never offering help. I think they all passed, the 11 other people left in the class.

>>17422844
>How often do you change your razor?
>Dont tell me you fall for the “every 5-7 shaves” jew
>I change my every 2 months

I use a Gillette Mach3. I usually get around 4 months' worth of daily shaves out of a cartridge before I start to get irritation. My beard is pretty heavy but I'm still young so my skin is soft and prone to irritation.
The trick is to rinse the blades off in alcohol before you put the razor away. Minerals in the water left on the blade form deposits on the cutting edges. Alcohol displaces the water so it's perfectly dry.

>>17422720
Harlembling is a good place to buy plated stuff online and afforadle chains. If you want diamonds, look into moissanite. Shines better than most diamonds and even pass testers, if you care about shit like that. Other than that, it's a gamble. If you're cool with something other than gold, sterling silver chains are pretty affordable. I mostly wear stainless steel because that shit shines and is dirt cheap. You can find 14mm Cubans for $12. But from my experience, it's a gamble if you're looking for plated stuff, since some people say their stuff hasn't tarnished and some people have their necks turning green. But hey as long as it looks good and shines the way you want it, it doesn't matter if you didn't pay shit for it. Hope this helps, anon good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17424016
That's nice but the reality is that the suit is pretty much dead now. Once upon a time everyone wore a suit for all occasions, then it became the uniform for only office jobs, and now it's the uniform for maybe every 1 in 50 office jobs.

And it's only going to become less and less of a uniform over the next 10 years. If you want to wear a suit, you have to just do it and accept that you will stand out.
But also try to realize that just because you stand out, doesn't mean you look bad, you just stand out. If you were wearing a banana suit, you would stand out, but it would also be retarded. But the suit looks good and nobody can deny that.
You will stand out, but you will also look good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

I like Hugo, but he seems to live in a different universe. He talks about going to all these Italian places where everyone is dressing up but it isn't true.
Go to googlestreetview, browse Italy, browse London, browse Paris. There is nobody dressing up. You might see the odd guy wearing a suit for work but it's a poorly fitted suit and he is not wearing it becaue he likes it.

Kirby is worse for this, in one of his recent videos he was talking about going to London and how he has to wear black shoes and a dark grey suit because that's what everyone is wearing in London... but nobody is wearing that, it's not reality.

Maybe they are doing it for marketing I don't know but dressing in a suit is not making other people comfortable unless you're in the company of other people wearing suits. If you want to make other people comfortable with your clothes, you have to be wearing the same thing as they are, which is most likely a tshirt and jeans.
And if you don't want to wear that and you do want to wear a suit, then you are not going to be making others comfortable, you are not going to be fitting in.

In America there's a common cliche about how neckties are like nooses. Gen X got the idea into their heads that the white collar worker was oppressed and that the tie was a symbol of his slavery. What followed was a forceful and enduring rejection of traditional menswear under the pretense that no one would willingly wear it. This is why the whole "you're awfully dressed up, got a job interview?" meme exists.

And thanks, it's my favorite tie. I just got this wool one recently that I really like as well. Goes great with a brown suit and a blue shirt. Cost me $24.99 on clearance. Brooks Brothers bankruptcy, the pandemic and cultural change combined to leave a ton of their old inventory orphaned. It's starting to get thin but you can still go into any thrift store in America and walk out with a high quality fashionable used tie for $1.99.

I struggle with shirts a lot. I lock myself into fairly tame solids for fear of having difficulty coordinating. I've got half a dozen plain white shirts. It does make it so that more interesting ties have room to breathe though.

Post some of your ties. 60+ is a lot.

The only thing that matters for looking good is everything about your person looking as proportionally flattering as possible, which is quantifiable by way of an ideal 'contextually appropriate' ratio, eg. vitruvian proportions, or, for comprehensibility, pericean semiotic triad. As living creatures, we all have acute awareness of vestigiality and redundancy. Overdressing signals, by evincing severe mental conflict, the same disgust-self preservation reaction (manifesting as ostracization) as seeing a leper. Thus, gigachad sexcore is not flattering. Neither is looking like a 90's NBA player. Sartorially, such proportional attention means hand craft somewhere in the process, and a baseline of self awareness from a third person perspective on the part of the wearer/consumer. These criteria aren't possible to satisfy with factory mass production or consumer demand/consumer manipulation patterns. People don't dress well because they suffer on a spectrum and cultural heritage of ugliness and failure, a trend present both internally and externally.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Long ass post but there's a clothing-related point.
For the winter I bought a merino wool thermal layer for my legs. I found a pair that were 100% merino for a good price. When I unwrapped them, they were literally SO stretchy that I had to re-check the label to make sure they had 0% synthetics. And theyre not itchy at all. After a couple months of wearing the same pair every work day, there's no sign of wear. This is proof that the idea that clothing like socks and underwear absolutely NEED synthetics for durability and stretch is complete BULLSHIT. You don't need to put plastic on your body.

Also, when I was looking for merino socks, I read info on a manufacturer's website that was very enlightening. Their socks were ~40% wool and then 10-20% each of various synthetics. They claimed that this was because the different synthetics all had different qualities that made the perfect sock. Yet It also said that, by US law, wool MUST be the largest single material to market it as wool clothing. So they basically admitted that they use a melange of 4 synthetics just to ensure that wool is still technically the plurality, so they can be legally labeled as merino socks. Another reason not to trust the narrative that synthetics are for performance and not cost-cutting.

posts.com:
>>17420550
>Armaf Niche Oud
Ambery, warm frag. There are some spices but I can't really detect them. Supposedly a clone of Ambre Sultan, although I haven't tried it. The drydown reminds me a bit of Bentley for Men Intense, although I get an incensey church vibe from it. Very good longevity and great sillage for hours. I just have a decant and I still haven't finished it in over a year. Just 1-3 sprays is more than enough.
>Mancera Sahara Wind
Leathery, slightly spicy, soapy. Reminds me of a old man's shaving soap in a good way. Less projection and longevity but still above average to me.
>Kenzo Jungle
Fresh, woody/spicy frag, a little powdery to my nose. I get a note that I can't really explain (could be the mate or guaiac wood) which I haven't really smelled before but it does smell nice. Decent for warm weather but I've never worn it on a very hot day. This is the lightest frag in terms of projection but still a decent performer and does last a long time on my skin, although I go heavier on the sprays.

Anyone else worn this? I picked up a bottle after getting a sample in my Luckyscent order. It's another fragrance that heavily features Akaigalawood but it doesn't smell like Ganymede,BI, or Kenzo Intense at all. Roland is more of a fuzzy, musky fragrance with Oud and florals coated with a candied vanilla shell.

I find it fascinating how this fragrance features more "delicate" ingredients than the other tree but the Akaigalawood doesn't overpower them and make itself the center of attention here.
If you're looking for an interesting unisex fragrance that doesn't quite smell like anything else out there, give Roland a shot

3: Their whole stick is the high percentage of oils. Well,turns out that's a sort of half truth. Multiple turbo autists ran DUA and Alexandria fragrances through shit like gas chromatography and other tests and then released the results. Turns out that yes the fragrance may technically be an extrait strength due to oil percentage but the bulk of the oils were inert carrier oils like jojoba. So the actual percent of fragrant oils is at EDT levels at best, rarely EDP. Never extrait.

But they leave a greasy smear on your skin so small brain pajeets "know" that means more oil and more oil means better so they gobble the swill up.

Rasasi may make a clone of Oud Wood and sell it, but they will also sell the concoction they used to make the clone in bulk. DUA can't do that, all they can do is buy someone else's work and then dilute it with oil and claim it's a masterpiece.

I am honestly glad Carlos died so I don't ever have to see that drunk simpering faggot fawn all over a DUA product so they send him more booze money


Other clone houses are thieves but they actually do the work to reverse engineer (sort of) the fragrance. DUA basically exists off their flotsam.

>>17421070
>How do I make sure it’s genuine
By doing a lot of research and getting to know the brand and the watches they produced. Seikos for instance all have their reference number on the dial under the 6 o'clock marker and you can work from there.
>what should I usually ask the seller?
Just basic stuff, photos help a ton.
>Should I get a pic of the mechanism?
Not that important, it matters more whether it has been serviced recently or not.
>What should I expect from an accuracy stand point.
Not much to be honest. Mechanical watches, especially older ones, aren't that accurate to begin with, generally they can be brought down to around +/- a minute per day i would say, that i would consider acceptable. I haven't checked mine yet because i rarely wear them.

posts.com:
>>17421030
>what are some good watches to start with?
Anything as long as the dial and the case are in good condition (steer away from bad discoloration on the dial, uneven patina, banged up cases or worn off plating).
Known brands are a plus but if you only focus on that you'll miss out on a lot of interesting watches.
Don't buy watches that don't work, they will cost a fortune to get them running and sometimes, if the movement is an obscure one, they won't have spare parts to be able to repare it.
> what should I be looking for to make sure its genuine?
If the dial looks impeccable compared to the case, it's almost certainly a reprinted dial or a new one. Vintage dials can look good but they are never perfect. Look at the indexes, the hands and the dots on the face of the dial, they should show the passage of time like some marks on the dial and indexes and darkened dots.
For the movement, if one part looks unusually clean compared to the others, then it's probably unoriginal. Ask for the caliber reference and photos and look on the internet to see if everything matches.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17421030
> I want to get a pic rel and a vintage doxa. What should I expect from an accuracy stand point and what other useful questions I should ask the seller?
Both great pics, Eterna has made some incredible and reliable automatic watches from the 40s up until the 70s. Doxa also made some great dress watches too. Both thoses watches can be purchased under 300$ serviced if you get a good deal on it and spare parts are available.
If the seller is a professionnal, ask him a picture of the watch on a timegrapher, it should give all the informations you want accuracy-wise. You should be able to have +/-30sec if well serviced and regulated.
If you buy your watch comes from someone that isn't a watchmaker and claims it was serviced, ask for the service receipt. If he doesn't have it, the watch was 99% not serviced. If it hasn't been serviced in a while, keep in mind you'll probably have to have it serviced and it'll cost a few hundred.

I'm missing so much informations but really when you stumble upon something you like, look on the internet the brand, the caliber and similar models to get as much knowledge as possible.

posts.com: I think the problem is, today there are so many different styles of architecture and interior design. Compared to the early 20th century when there was basically a singular generally accepted style. Of course there was regional variation and rich eccentrics who built extravagant mansions, but the average people all appreciated a certain style. So today real estate developers/sellers want to create homes with the most basic design possible so that the owners can then customize it to fit whatever look they want. When they get their hands on an older house with wallpaper, ornate trim, or mosaic tiles, they'll cover it up with white paint so as not to offend any potential buyer. Of course the problem with that is only upper or upper-middle class people are going to have the money to actually make their house look cool. Everyone else lives in white drywall NPC pods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17423304
Pretty fucking basic tips:

READ THE CARE LABEL. AND ACTUALLY DO WHAT IT SAYS.

If in doubt, HAND WASH. Especially if it's special to you.

Buy wool detergent Or I swear to god I will find you, and I will suffocate you with all of your destroyed, felted woollen sweaters/socks.

Don't be fucking lazy. If the tag says dry clean, then take it to the dry cleaners. I destroyed a gorgeous pair of viscose trousers by being a fucking cheap lazy ass and handwashing it. It never got that beautiful soft texture back.

Why do you own a dryer? Seriously? Are you that fucking willing to just throw money away? Get a drying rack and hang it outside. Don't care where you live, whether you have a balcony or a communal courtyard, put it outside in a bit of wind and sun to dry. Even if you hang it on your shower rack for 24 hrs, it's still better than tumble drying. You could probably do with some sunlight anyway. In winter, put it a safe distance from a heater and it'll dry within 24 hrs.

Invest in stain removers and whitening treatments. Spray affected areas, scrub if necessary. My GOOD whites I always pre-treat with a soak before washing like normal.

Separate colours. Don't be lazy.

For the love of god, stop wearing aluminium deodorants. They destroy your clothes. If you really stink so much, then maybe cut white out of your wardrobe.

Basically, laundry is never a one-and-done task, unless you're a Zuckerbergian freak.

Oh yeah, and pick up a sewing kit. They rarely cost over $5, and it saves you time and money taking it to a repairer. It's really not a hard skill to learn. Patching up busted seams, loose or replacement buttons, it's all so much easier than just tossing that garment away. ESPECIALLY if you invest in vintage or archival garments. But hell, most fast fashion pieces are falling apart in a fraction of the time those clothes have been on earth, let alone on your fat body.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17423482
Oh yeah, and some environmental tips.

Don't leave good woollen coats out in the open. It's really worth buying those plastic suit covers to keep them in, just in case you end up with a moth infestation.

Speaking of, regularly clean out your closet. I'm talking like seasonal wardrobe deep clean. Even if you aren't tossing or getting rid of anything, keeping the space your clothes are stored in vacuumed and wiped down will also extend the longevity of pieces.

And hey, I often forego this step, but washing second hand garments as soon as they enter your home is always a good idea. I know it's just easier to throw it in your wardrobe, but you really never know what you might be introducing to the biosphere of your garments when you feign this crucial step. Just don't think twice about it, toss it in a wash cycle, or even throw it in a bucket with some detergent and water.

I know this also seems unnecessary, keeping woollen sweaters in containers during off-seasons, but its a good idea. And before putting them away, as well as when getting them back out, letting them air out in the sun will stave off any old dusty smells. If you're seriously precious, get some moth balls, but I find the smell too strong to justify it. As long as the container is fairly airtight, it should be fine.

Also, as soon as you get any sort of spills (food, dirt, paint, whatever) on something, don't rub it, just carefully blot it with a napkin or tissue until you can get somewhere to wash it out. I'm OCD and I get up straight away to run it under water, but if you're out in public, don't try to 'wipe' or 'rub' it off, and don't forget about it when you get home. Wash it out straight away.
Some fabrics are exceptionally hardy and can be redeemed from stains even after a few days, but it will require more elbow grease, and also you never want to face the disappointment of it not being the case. [spoiler]white t-shirts[/spoiler]

Take pride in your garments, care for them properly.
